commentBody: New Saturday PB. 5:22. Played like a Wednesday puzzle.
Third PR this week after Monday and Tuesday. Not complaining but curious‚Ä¶what gives?
Full of fun stuff, but it solved very quickly for a Saturday puzzle. I didn't know OZLEM, but it was easy to get from the crosses.
Whew! Killer northwest corner for me. Nice Saturday challenge.
yesterday was a Saturday. this was a Wednesday.

After a tougher than usual (for these days) Friday, I was disappointed but not surprised to find an easy Saturday.
It's a perfectly fine puzzle (thanks, Adam), but not much of a challenge. If Wednesdays sometimes have rebuses or other wordplay, why can't they sometimes be easier themelesses?
Give us challenges on Friday and Saturday please!

A slow start, but smashed my PR.

Have a great weekend!
A good Saturday. Better than my average. Got stuck on ASU (Appalachian State University) who are also Mountaineers. Learned things, too. Thanks!
A minute faster than the Friday, and I was somewhat distracted during the solve
They snuck in at 30D!!!

UMACTUALLY, I rather liked this one, and had BUSHELS of fun solving it, although UMACTUALLY flummoxed me for a bit. I hesitated to put in BUSHELS because I couldn‚Äôt see how U could be the first letter of 26D.  I also tried date and time before TAKE, which made it harder to unlock the NE.  I loved seeing ACTDUMB and BRAINPOWER side by side.

Avocados guac my world.

(These puns are the pits.)

I never ‚Äî never ‚Äî finish a Saturday puzzle without checking this column. This one I did without that, going to the internet for the Ozlem answer, which is so obscure I don‚Äôt consider it cheating. And, even better, I beat my very high average for a Saturday puzzle. All you geniuses can whine all you want, but I appreciate a doable Saturday. Thanks.
4D in the mini, 4D in the main xword. Holt.Coincidence, or something deeper?
Ozlem Tureci deserves to be better known. She did the mRNA research that led to our quickly developed COVID  vaccines in 2020.

This was a Saturday?  Seems like a mistake.  One of my fastest ever, and not particularly challenging despite some out-there names.

I expect to see a LOT of complaints about "um actually".  This is one.  It st_nks.  Other than that (and the obscure names) a decent puzzle, perhaps better for a Wednesday?

This was a Saturday? Seems like a mistake.  One of my fastest ever, and not particularly challenging despite some out-there names.

I expect to see a LOT of complaints about "um actually". This is one. It st__ks. Other than that (and the obscure names) a decent puzzle, perhaps better for a Wednesday?

(Second try past the emus.  Apologies if it is a double.)

Wow. I didn't think I'd ever best my Saturday time but there it is (I beat my fastest Thursday and Friday times too). Way too easy for me (just my opinion, not everyone has the same wheelhouse). And now I can go to bed early! üò¥ Enjoy the weekend friends!
Somehow I was convinced that the period coinciding with the growth of the internet should be something unrelated to the internet itself, and so, went for SITCOM BOOM. (DOPE SLAP).

Get your facts first!? What!? Who has got that kind of time these days, amiright or amiright!?  Har!  There are socials to post on, comments to make, and a hefty MEDIADIET to consume‚Äîdon't bore me with your facts. Facts-shmacts, I tell you!! 

Oh, a little carried away by the Twain quote? It happens. But now I'll return to your regularly scheduled program, the puzzle.  

Enjoyable puzzle all around. Once again, sailed through except that pesky NW gets me so often! But, once I had my big duh moment and remembered that it's BELLA not prima at 17A, which I had just put in without even a tiny KERNEL of scrutiny when BELLA filled in. Stopped with the DUMBACT, fixed it and the rest simply manifested before my very peepers‚Äîhuzzah!  Might have been a pb if not for that. Pb? Nb! 

Liked ACTDUMB and BRAINPOWER nestled together and that AVOCADO and LIME were both in it. Mmmm!

UMACTUALLY, I really liked that entry. This recent visit to Honduras, my favorite 13 year old (UMACTUALLY, probably my favorite human between my husband's age and 13) kept saying this phrase. 

Like, if I'd been doing shots for every time, I'd had some serious hangovers, but... it was super endearing and always interesting to hear what she had to say. It was always MEANtWELL not snarky, as I suppose it could be.    

Speaking of MEANSWELL... what a loaded idiom, I tell you! 

Anyhow, happy weekend!

I interrupted my retirement to take a cruise to Mexico. With little else to angst over, I wondered about how well the boat WiFi would work and whether I‚Äôd stay on top of my puzzles. Add to that, I usually solve with a posse, left behind in Puyallup. Well, one down and two to go. No KPop. No post 2000 media stars. Just smooth sailing to a solve in just half my usual Saturday time. Whew.

I found this puzzle much easier than yesterday's - I solved it in Wednesday time, and without lookups. Ok, well, I did google one thing once I did not get my gold star upon filling the final square. There were a few spots that looked weird to me (JARTS? Never heard of it before. Why is ARCH playful in tone? My archenemy standing under an arch hardly seems playful; OZLEM and WVU were new to me, too), but in the end it proved to be the composer, who apparently is an ERIK rather than an ERIc. PREc puzzled me, sure, but PREK is almost equally alien to me. Is that short for pre-kindergarten? I assume it is.

I still remember how surprised I was by the English word kindergarten when I learned it some 35 years ago. Why are we speaking German now, I thought. In Polish it's simply called "przedszkole" (preschool, which functions in English, too). The place for even younger kids is "≈º≈Çobek." The word has an interesting etymology. It is related to "≈º≈Ç√≥b", manger, as in the trough for animal feed. ≈ª≈Ç√≥bek, literally "little manger", is where baby Jesus slept. Linguists assume ≈º≈Çobek as a term for Pre-K arose out of the biblical story. Also, for some more Polish trivia: ≈º≈Çobek is pronounced slightly differently than ≈º≈Ç√≥bek - the thing over the o matters; we pronounce "o" as you do your "o" in bog or cog, whereas our "√≥" is your "oo" of boom or book.

For a minute, I really thought [Flummox] which I knew was going to end UMP, was going to start with a T followed by and R.

I thought to myself, looks like someone is lighting dynamite sticks.
Easy but fun puzzle with nice, clean fill. TIL dot com boom refers to the stock market's performance and not to the actual uptick in the use of the internet during that period.

So a minute off my fastest Saturday time, enough said, It doesn‚Äôt seem like I‚Äôm in a minority on this. I did think BEBE and BABA and ABBA at the top was kind of cute. Nothing else to comment on, I know the constructor MEANSWELL.
That ‚Äúeye drop‚Äù theory of BELLADONNA‚Äôs really sounds like folk etymology. Are there any scholarly sources supporting the claim?

In just a few short days, Benny has gathered an ardent following! I recall saying that I wish that I could post pictures, so instead I'm going to plug his insta: @foxy_benny. I eschew social media so don't have my own account, but these 2 are just too adorable (in my very biased opinion) to not have an account of their own. 

Benny is still dopey from meds, but is slowly recovering to his old self. Benny thanks all of you for your love, well wishes and support.

It‚Äôs a small pet peeve. But I wish there was one, set, NYT, accepted spelling for tsar, tzar, and czar. I struggle enough with the American idioms and brand names.  But also this was a very good puzzle and I enjoyed it.

My fastest Saturday puzzle and first time I didn't need hints! There were a few that stumped me but the crossings resolved them. Clever clues today.

Also I live in Germany so the Biontech guy is someone who is pretty well known. He was on TV here quite a bit during the pandemic.

UMACTUALLY must have started life as a Mike Trapp/Ify Nwadiwe clue, right?

A quick, fun fill for me today, where each answer unlocked boxes for the other direction. I definitely stared for a while at ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢DOOIL before the OIL separated out.

Had to laugh at myself when I got stuck without my gold star, only to realize it was the stinking U in EMU (of all words!) that was jamming me up. I had WVa, thinking West Virginia, and convinced myself that ‚ÄúEMa‚Äù must be an indigenous tribe.

I didn‚Äôt find this puzzle especially easy.

Then again, I was watching Happy Gilmore 2 as I solved. And I thoroughly enjoyed it.

So, yes, I was a bit distracted. But given my MEDIA DIET, it might already be clear to many of you that I didn‚Äôt start the puzzle with much BRAIN POWER to begin with.

Got BELLADONNA thanks to alchemy skill  in the game Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2.

Beat my average by over an hour. Thanks, videogames.

I need help...not with solving the puzzles though.  Up until yesterday I had a 2,206 day consecutive solving streak going. However yesterday, despite my solving the (Friday) puzzle shortly after it came out; my streak was stopped.  After solving the Sat. puzzle today,  it now says my streak is 1 day, though it admits that I have a 316 day streak of completed Saturday puzzles. Does anyone know who I can contact to get my daily streak reestablished?  I know it might sound dumb, and it's not something I ever mention to anyone, but it's still meaningful to me.  Thanks for any help you can offer!
Like a lot of contributors it seems, pretty easy today‚Ä¶ done before I‚Äôd finished my lunchtime beer‚Ä¶
Not really understanding ARCH here, nice easy breezy Saturday (more like a soft Wednesday imo)

I enjoyed the puzzle, although I must have less BRAIN POWER than most of you. My solve time was around :35, which beat my average, but still far slower than you brainiacs. But since I don‚Äôt solve for time, I don‚Äôt actually care. (You may read this as an ARCH comment. üòâ)

I must take exception to Caitlin‚Äôs assertion that the dot-com boom/ Internet age changed humanity for good. Lately, I‚Äôve become less certain that the many benefits are worth the downside. With greater access to facts comes greater access to ‚Äúalternative‚Äù facts, which for too many are indistinguishable from the real deal. Distortion without facts has become a way of life, and I think Mark Twain would be appalled by our ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù society.
Is UMACTUALLY the sequel to a very popular Brit rom-com from he early 90s, in which the characters realize they've coupled with the wrong partner?

Aiyo
Came out the CRIB with a blade in my CLASP,
AVOCADO OIL in the skillet ‚Äî cook fast,
DOT COM BOOM, but I move like it‚Äôs ‚Äô96,
Slick TIGER in the jungle with them iron fists.

Used to CURTSY to the gods in the JACUZZI,
Now I light BUSHELS of haze, blow it loosely.
PACK ANIMAL moves, I‚Äôm a mule with the stash,
Wool trench, MAX .40 tucked next to the cash.

BELLADONNA kiss ‚Äî poison on her lips,
Tried to TEMPTS FATE, got laced in the script.
No IDLE hands ‚Äî I grip KEYS to the safe,
In this GAME of deceit, SEES lies on the face.

MEDIA DIET, I don‚Äôt feed off clout,
I PREFERS solitude ‚Äî let the whispers sprout.
From UNSUNG blocks, where the angels fell,
Now it‚Äôs cream in the pocket ‚Äî MEANS WELL, can‚Äôt tell.

I found this puzzle really easy, which is not a brag because I will freely admit I‚Äôm usually waaaaaay slower than most of you. There was just some magic for me in this one - I love when that happens! You get that temporary smug smarty pants feeling that is almost always dispelled the following day ‚Ä¶

Very pleased with a sub 13 minute clear time and no assists, which is definitely not normal for me on a Saturday. Had quite a struggle with Friday‚Äôs puzzle. They could have switched days and it would have felt totally appropriate.

Wow a Friday then a Saturday I enjoyed. First time ever - hope this a trend.
Fun clues which gradually revealed themselves - some made me laugh.
Shouldn‚Äôt the clue to 55 Across be ‚Äúrun, but not move‚Äù, or alternatively the answer should be IDLEing.

That was a fun puzzle, with a few chewy areas. I stared at the few letters I had for 25D -ALANC‚Äî-E completely mystified. A good chuckle when I finally got it. Ditto 13A.
Wanted stymy for STUMP so that slowed me a little. dARTS and not knowing the BioNtec chap meant I couldn‚Äôt see JACUZZI either. But it turned into a pretty fast solve for me overall. Very enjoyable.

Yesterday‚Äôs post was eaten by the denizens of the Great Victoria Desert. I presume because I obliquely alluded to the subject matter of most of Mr Colbert‚Äôs monologues, of whom I‚Äôm a huge fan. Stephen that is.

This would be an excellent puzzle for someone new to solving Saturday puzzles.  It's on the easier range of Saturday difficulty, but it presents enough of a challenge to build confidence to tackle more difficult Saturdays.  And, of course, it's just a fun puzzle to solve!

BELLADONNA made me think of Beth March in "Little Women", so I did a search to check and at the top of the results was the AI Overview:

'In "Little Women," Beth March does not use or mention belladonna.'

UM ACTUALLY...

"I looked in Mother's book, and saw that it begins with headache, sore throat, and queer feelings like mine, so I did take some belladonna, and I feel better," said Beth." (Chapter 17)

As it says in the fine print, "AI responses may include mistakes."
Good Wednesday puzzle.

Gently . . . Did this puzzle, which I enjoyed, accidentally run on the wrong day? As in, I solved it in a significantly faster time than any average time on *any* day (over two minutes faster than my Monday average, a over 21 minutes faster than my Saturday average, and faster than Weds, Thurs, and Friday of this week). Looking at previous comments this seems to be a theme. I very much prefer my 25-minute Saturdays and would not like to see them go the way of recent Thursdays.

"...I frankly did not want vaguer alternatives that would only make things more difficult."

But Caitlin, isn't that the point of a Saturday puzzle?  

My opinion?  This was a high quality puzzle with lots of interesting fill that was let down by the ease of the clues.

I really, really liked Adam‚Äôs fill and clueing. 

Wish the editors had run it early in the week.

Minority opinion here. Most comments about level of difficulty are calling this one too easy to be a Saturday. 

For whatever reason, this one took me a tad longer than usual, and while not terribly difficult, hardly qualified as one of the easier Saturdays for me. 

Those would be when I didn‚Äôt have to jump around looking for a foothold. I did get started without too much trouble, but I hardly moved effortlessly through the grid. 

Different strokes, I guess.

Weather report: Hot enough for long enough to where my dog Teddy has splendidly mastered the splat sploot.




Et tu, emu.

I always thought that JARTS was a brand name for the game of "lawn darts".
JAvelin dARTS?  Really???

On Saturday I want:
‚Ä¢	At least a couple of out-and-out never-heard-of no-knows to overcome. Check.
‚Ä¢	A wealth of answers that appeal. Check.
‚Ä¢	Vague clues that make me wait for crosses, or make me guess.  Check.
‚Ä¢	Enough footholds to keep me fired up, but sparse enough to make me earn my squares. Check.

Regarding those answers that appealed to me: BELLADONNA, JACUZZI, PACK ANIMAL, TEMPTS FATE, KERNELS, ECLIPSE, AARGH, BRAIN POWER, ARCH (as clued).  It lifts the day to amble through delights such as these. 

Neither slog nor dash through the park, this fell in my happy zone ‚Äì thank you, Adam!
I was in TROUBLE for a while until I realised what hot water meant.

Quite the solid Saturday puzzle, though my impression was that some of the cluing seemed a bit too direct for a Saturday. Last entry filled was ARCH, since I don't think I'm familiar with the usage in the clue. 

I think I've wondered this before, but how did "lawn darts" transform into JARTS? Perhaps this is already discussed in the column or comments?

I found this a lot easier than yesterday, the clues suited me more. I assumed 'smarts' had something to do with being painful, stinging. Then I remembered the phrase 'He's got smarts' which always seemed to be a bit odd!

In the minority here (hi Steve). Actually found this one unusually tough for a Saturday. More than a couple of complete unknowns and others that were not going to dawn on me just from the clues. Had to look some things up, but managed to get through it. 

And... puzzle finds today were something I've never encountered before. First - a Monday from February 1, 1999 by Dorothy Smitonick. Three theme answers in that one: 

REVOLVINGDOOR
WHIRLINGDERVISH
SPINNINGWHEEL

And then... a Monday from July 8, 2013 by Randy Sowell. Three theme answers in that one (in the same order): 

REVOLVINGDOOR
WHIRLINGDERVISH
SPINNINGWHEEL

Could that possibly just be a coincidence? Hmmm.  Have to wonder about that. 

I'm done. 

....

Fun one.

Grew up outside Chicago.
Fire drills were a thing, as they are for everyone,
but easily twice as often, 
we had tornado drills.

Everyone down to the school basement.
Sit against the wall, 
windows cracked,
knees up, 
arms around legs,
face buried.
No talking.

Dozens of times.
No biggie.

Except once.
There were tornadoes spotted in the area.
Close by.

In the quiet halls of the basement,
fear had nestled itself between us kiddos,
and then I heard a voice 
echoing from another hallway.

It was my mom.
She took my hand and my sister‚Äôs 
and we ran the three blocks to our house,
and straight down to the cellar.

The sky was green.
No wind.
No sound of birds.
The creepiest calm I‚Äôve ever experienced.

We got hit.
Not our house, but our town.

But those 5 minutes running 
through the most odd version of 
my neighborhood‚Ä¶
with my mamma‚Äôs hand gripping mine so tightly,
determined to get us 
home and safe‚Ä¶

Anyway, have a lovely Saturday all!

@ Andrzej

Just got Wordle in 2 (really), extending my streak to 61356 (not really).
When the facts change, I change my mind. Attributed to Keynes.
You are entitled to your opinions, but you are not entitled to your facts. Moynihan
I found this one particularly easy for a saturday! but no complaints here! I really enjoyed the clues and the grid. starting off my Saturday beautifully! I hope everyone is having a good weekend!
Friday and Saturday definitely got flipped this week lol

I've found recently that I have more gold stars for Thursday-Saturday than I do Sunday-Wednesday.  I use the easier puzzles for speed runs.  When I finish the puzzle and there's something wrong, I don't have the patience to flyspeck, so I hit "check puzzle", correct, and move on.  Whereas with the harder puzzles I really try to suss it out.  

With today's I had 3-4 clues filled in on first pass, really thought I wouldn't be able to finish without help, but gradually sussed it out.  A perfect degree of difficulty for me, though some of those proper nouns were tough.  Is the founder of a biotech company that I'd wager almost none of us have heard of a clue we should have in our brains?

I truly miss the days when Saturday would have me stumped and I would have to come back to it throughout the day, possibly never solving it. Now it's a quarter of an hour Iater and I'm done.

There is nothing wrong with harder clues and relying on specialized, non-contemporary, non-pop/slang knowledge. Learning and thinking are fun.

To the archives, I suppose. Sigh.

Hmm 164 Comments already....and how many are going to echo my same feeling?--to wit:  this was much easier than yesterday's puzzle!!  Do you feel you've been toyed with?  
AS DO I...or AS AM I?

GASP! Before GAPE
UNSEEN before UNSUNG
(DIGS) in the margin before ROOM
(TSAR) in the margin with CZAR

PEANUT OIL has a high smoke point; I've never bought or used AVOCADO OIL.  Does it have other properties that would make it superior?  (Bill in Detroit??)

I SOLVED A SATURDAY PUZZLE WITHOUT LOOKUPS! I do not know how that happened. There were plenty things I didn‚Äôt know but I just kept plugging away at it, correcting answers, making educated guesses, etc. Today is going to be a good day! üòä

Digging through the asbestos-covered xword archives I‚Äôve noticed some pretty easy saturdays and many more hard ones. I think that‚Äôs still true. No cause for panic. Also, my ‚ÄúGoogle-fu‚Äù must be weak cuz after 15 aggravating minutes I couldn‚Äôt find an answer to this quest-e-o-nay so I pose it to this reliable brain trust‚Ä¶. Is this the same Gary Larson who does the Far Side comics?
Given the infamous guacamole recipe in the NYT Cooking section, I initially thought 49D was looking for PEAS.
Who else noticed that the Mini and the Crossword had a Down-word in common?
It was hard for me to get a toehold in this one, but once I did it went very quickly. Even with OZLEM.

Put me in the "happy for a Saturday with no look-ups for once" column. Going from practically nothing to completion was an enjoyable 30+ minutes indeed.
I was so proud of myself for plopping in BATHTUB for 46A. Pride goeth..... Had to admit that I'd need DITTO or SOAMI or ASAMI or one of them there, however. Finally got the Z and then yay! 
Thanks to everyone who explained JARTS. Doh!
  My Janeite creds are going to be revoked for not getting ARCH till the crosses. Used in nearly every Austen novel!
  liked UMACTUALLY. I was working for some variant of IMAHAVEAN??? for a long time.
My first ever Saturday solve fully on my own - it must have been a little easier? Even so, it's going to be a good day!

I thought the grid was full of interesting words but I thought the puzzle was too easy for a Saturday.   It took me 11 minutes versus my average of 26.   But reading the comments here, all I can say is that at least some people enjoyed the relative easiness. I am happy for them.
Always intrigued how the editors manage to publish the Crossword and Mini with linked or matching word, such as today. And they were both  4-Down! üåñ
I love seeing all of the game stats on one page but miss the crossword solve times all being visible on same graph.
Wait a minute-I thought it was Saturday
Wow a breezy Saturday after Friday‚Äôs slogfest.

That was bussin! (To clarify for the olds, I MEAN SWELL.)


Is 48D saying that infants are exploitative?

(Second attempt - can't blame the EMUs for losing my wi-fi.)

I may not have seen every installment of the "Fast and Furious" franchise, but all of the street racers drove 2-door coupes, not 4-door SEDANs. I'm accustomed to NYCers' being blissfully unaware of all things automotive, but c'mon man!

Some where, out there, Ozrem Rexha is having a special day.
For a while I had SEXTAPE in 40D, but once I fixed that this went rather fast. Nice puzzle.

I may not have seen every installment in the "Fast and Furious" franchise, but I'm pretty sure all the street racers were driving coupes, not SEDANs. I'm accustomed to NYCers being blissfully ignorant of cars in general, but that's next-level ignorance.

Some where, out there, Ozlem Rexha is having a special day.
It‚Äôs just cruel that nightshade and BELLADONNA have the exact same number of letters
15:58, new record for a Saturday! Ok time to do laundry now.

Really loved the experience of solving today's Saturday puzzle!  It was difficult to break into, and the solve mostly consisted of adding a letter here a word there until finally it was magically all filled in. It was ridiculously hard for me to finally see the first letter M of _AX for "Uppermost limit".

The one clue/answer that seemed a bit silly to me was 27D "Sites of mutations on chromosomes" for LOCI, sine loci is just a word meaning "sites".

I usually can expect to work on the Saturday puzzle on and off, in between tasks, I won't call them chores, for the most part I enjoy puttering around getting things done, but not today! I haven't even started my list of things to do, but the puzzle is done! 

After yesterday's, which DID take me all day, it was nice surprise.

Stay cool everybody.

I found this one tough and had to employ Check Puzzle pretty early on and do a lot of solving employing the Wheel of Fortune method, but no look ups. My brain hasn't been firing on all cylinders lately. Stevie Nicks released an album entitled Bella Donna. Here's a duet with Tom Petty from it. https://youtu.be/H5i7j0VhEHw?si=4qXWql1i_UJXu8e4. Will the emus be mad that I didn't recognize the Great Victoria Desert immediately?

A very speedy Saturday, personally. I normally would have preferred a tougher and longer solve for a lazy Saturday morning, but I enjoyed all the fun factoids. Loved that just last night, I mentioned to my daughter that people used to put BELLADONNA in their babies‚Äô bottles (followed by a Google search, even learning about the Augustus rumor, and making that my first entry!), and OZLEM‚Äôs BioNTech is a past client of my firm. Love those coincidental personal gimmies!

Haha, good times.  Loved the crossing of JARTS with JACUZZI.  I remember summer days of jarts, drinking from the hose, and catching fireflies right after sunset.  Almost comical to think that jarts are illegal compared to other things.  Too bad our Founding Fathers didn‚Äôt play‚Ä¶
Good value for money today, as they say.  Enjoyed this one thoroughly for a Saturday entry.

This was an unexpected delight. I had more incorrect words the first time through than I can remember, and answer after answer I could only get through crosses that stomped over my previous answers.

I thought I was going to have my first complaint about an unfair cross (after 8 years), because I figured 22A could be an abbreviation for either 'pages' or 'pronouns' or something else, and I've mangled the spelling of 14D in various ways, depending on my level of frustration (including AARrg). 

Alas, once I'd figured out 26D started with a U, meaning 25A was BUSHELS, meaning 14D ended in an H (dope slap!), I was left with AAR_H and the cross was obvious. 

Once again NYT, you almost beat me with a totally fair cross. Not fair! Now I need a place to misdirect my righteous indignation! (Suggestions?)

My totally wonderful comment appears to have been EMU'd. Checking to see whether it was this phrase?

Dope slap

Being a very stubborn 38A, I refused to give up nightshade for 17A. Of course this caused the NE corner to be unsolvable. I tried every answer remotely conceivable for 13A before yelling 14D.

Needless to say, my solve time is slower than my 40D.
Nw corner...ARGh!!!

Will someone explain the emu joke to me please? 

(Related: look up the emu war for some avian fun)

About two and a half weeks ago, my streak disappeared and I emailed customer support. I got a reply about three days later, on a Friday, telling me what to do and my streak would be reset. Did it, waited until the following Tuesday, wrote again. Received an apology. My streak was fixed. Wrote a final time, "Yes! It all looks good. Sorry you guys have been swamped. Thank you--and all of NYT--for being there."

And, although swamped, the customer support specialist who had been working with me took the time to write this reply:

Hi Lynn,

Thanks so much for the kind words and support!

Please don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything going forward. One note, however, we are not in on the weekends so sometimes requests submitted near the end of the week and over the weekend will have a delayed response time. 

Please know that we will always get back to you!

All the best and happy solving!

(And she signed her name.)
Saturday record 11:01. < 1/3 of the time taken yesterday. Would have preferred these two to have been switched. I have more time on Saturdays.

When I finished this morning, I didn't remember any lookups, but I congratulated myself too soon. I was stumped enough to turn to the Column which gave me the entirety of 17A where I hadn't yet a single crossing. I think I used to know that was a poisonous plant but neither it nor anything else would have been on a list I tried to make of poisonous plants. It was the Column that told me what kind of DIET 20A was and filled in the rest of ____C_MBOOM (I must have heard of that in my younger days?) at 32A. That, plus a good night's sleep got me to a successful finish, although until told so I was still doubtful of some of my wild guesses. I would have doubted OZLEM except the crosses there were undeniable.

If the clue is a gerund must not the answer be a gerund?

Running, not moving: IDLING.

Run, not move: IDLE.

Whenever I finish a puzzle and it seems easier than usual, I assume that I'm either getting better at crosswords or I'm just particularly smart today - especially on a Saturday, when I'm usually caught up on sleep. I can't imagine any way to judge how hard these things are objectively, in a way that controls for the undeniable fact that somedays I'm a lot derpier than others. 

This one felt very hard at the start, but after getting a few word in place, it came together quickly - except the top left corner, the crossing of 1A and 1D. I love a good rum cake, but never heard a name for them other than rum cakes, and Ms Rexha was a stranger to me. Guess I'll have to listen to her work today so I'll be ready for next time.
My only quibble would be with the clueing for SEDAN. Coupes would be the more common racer to my mind.
I used to be an adventurer like you.  Then I took a jart to the knee...

Mine fits/works instead of MILK.
Null fits/works instead of LULL.
Balanced up fits/works instead of BALANCE DUE. 

All of which left me wondering WTH epys were.

 Otherswise, half my usual Saturday time, and in fact less than half the time for yesterday's puzzle.
My first finish of a Saturday <30'.  I'm sure it's not a big deal for many, but it is for me.  Yeah! Thank you
Great work, constructor.

Some comments today led to an answer history search, inspired by a miscount. I wondered about.. LITTLEDEUCECOUPE But... that's 16 letters. However, the most recent previous appearance of COUPE was in a Thursday puzzle from April 4, 2024 and in that one the clue for it was: "Little Deuce_____ (Beach Boys hit)" But... then I stumbled down another path and came across a Sunday puzzle from August 5, 1979 by Tap Osborn. One clue and answer in that one was: "Walter's transportation" PIDGEONCOUPE And some other theme answers (all with a proper name in the answers and all related to the proper name in the clue ). Some other examples (just the answers): CHERHOLDER WONGNUMBER SCHELLCOLLECTOR GOULDRUSHES HOLMGAME HUSTONTAXES CARRFARE WORLEYGIGS SOTHERNEXPOSURE And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=8/5/1979&g=60&d=D ....

I actually like an easier Friday, harder Saturday but this was fun!
I worried at first but finished in half my average with no cheats. So it may have been easier but I was puzzling it out all the way.  I thought this was beautiful, Adam.

A few late musings: I wondered if today was a PB--according to the stats page, last Nov. 23 I completed the puzzle in exactly one-half the time I did today!--That's nonsense! In any case, a very quick solve, most done on my lunch break at work. Does that mean the puzzle was easy? Well, as a hotel chef who bike-commutes to work year-round, several of the long entries came right away: I've already sung the praises of AVOCADO OIL to @MOL; and let me say from experience--Always wear a pair of BIKE GLOVES twice the weight that you think the weather warrants--you catch all the headwind on your hands! And who street-races in a coupe? Where's the sport in that? SEDANs, all the way: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FMNtnr0LKYk&list=RDFMNtnr0LKYk&start_radio=1 (To be fair, Ramblers were manufactured as coupes, and wagons, in addition to sedans.)
Really enjoyed this puzzle. Great, unique clues.
I found this one a challenge for sure. But a worthy Saturday puzzle. Thanks to Adam Levav and the whole team. I did need a little help,from Caitlin‚Äôs Tricky Clues.

@Francis also, if you want to know the process, I actually used CRIB as my first thought for ‚ÄúHome, in slang‚Äù and just immediately confirmed with the down clues. As in, ABBA was a gimme, CRIB was a maybe, but it gave me ACT, BRAIN, BIKE, and AB__ which I then immediately knew was ABET. So it was a tentative guess which I think was able to confirm straight away with crosses.

Francis,

I'm quite sure you can answer chemistry problems to which I -- and likely most others here -- wouldn't even understand the questions. Some of us have more skill with words than others.

I don't solve for speed, but this one went quickly. I see I was not alone in that experience.

We don‚Äôt use ‚Äòkindergarten‚Äô in the UK, it‚Äôs either nursery or playschool. @Helen Wright In NYC at least our experience is that kindergarten is more like what you describe as nursery school, as both kids were expected to have foundational skills in math, writing, and reading before first grade. I remember going in for my daughter‚Äôs birthday read aloud at the end of her kindergarten year, when she had chosen a book that she knew well and that had a lot of straightforward words in it. She wanted to be the one to read it to the class, so we just gave her a little support here and there if she needed it. The rest of the class was rapt‚Äîit was a new experience for them to have a book read to them by a peer. I‚Äôll never forget the looks on their faces, a mix of awe and inspiration.

@Heidi

I've long wondered why lies travel so much faster than the truth on the internet.

I mean, it's not even close.  Lies spread at least 100x faster than the truth.

I think maybe I know why:  there are more liars than truth tellers on the internet, and liars can move faster.

Liars are far more likely to fire off something they agree with than a truth-teller, who is taking at least some time to try to verify the content, or at least check it for reasonability.  

That significantly slows down truth-tellers--liars have no such constraint.

So the high liar to truth-teller ratio on the internet combined with how much faster liars can transmit lies than truth-tellers can transmit the truth, leads to an environment where the truth is at an enormous disadvantage.

I strongly vote that, on balance, the internet has greatly damaged society, maybe even fatally.

@NYC Traveler

Yeah, I guess the internet just exacerbated an already existing problem.

Supposedly Livia painted the figs in the courtyard with the poison that killed Augustus...but it would have taken quite a lot, so who knows?  In small amounts, it was a painkiller or a sleep aid.

I only remember that Beth had contracted scarlet fever (which is a strep infection that can, indeed, affect the heart if left untreated ....)  and Beth was not portrayed as a robust child, so....though she seemed to recover from the infection, she died after some years,   
Our daughter had a rash and high fever on her 3rd birthday, and I was upset when the doc diagnosed scarlet fever--until he said, "It's just strep; don't worry."  What a difference a hundred twenty years can make!

@MOL  My aunt had it as a toddler and almost died. It left her with permanent health issues but she still lived well into her 90s, until last year.

She and my dad used to talk about what it was like in their house during her long illness.

First of all, we haven't actually moved yet.  I did take two carloads of stuff up to the new house yesterday, and came back just before 10:00, but I don't think I was especially tired.
